title: Sandvine | Applogic networks | Feedback | Bangalore India |
content:
Interview Level: Medium
Interview Rounds: 2-3 Rounds little chances of 4 rounds.
Questions: DSA close to medium level , most focus will be on your type of past work experience that you have done.
Verdict: if you are experienced folks give it least priority join only if it meets your expectation else a strong NO.
There are a lot of non-sense stuffs within the company even after applogic acquired it.
it has gone from a public to private company due to US government Sanctions.
There is no such thing in this company which you should consider to join here, my personal advice would be Avoid Joining.
Below are the points you should keep in your mind
If you are 0-2 years experience and you don't have much better options then you can consider joining bcz it pays (16-17 Lakh INR CTC) well in 0-2 years of experience and also for freshers it should be OK to start your carrer with but keep in mind side by side you should continue learning extra stuffs bcz here nowdays they are not dealing with any latest updated tech stuffs or anything so you have to move out once you complete junior level experience.
if you are 3+ YOE Avoid Joining or give it least priority or try for better.
if in case you have 3+ YOE and the HR are able to come to a fair mutual aggrement be it your compensation or WLB or anything else according to your Priority you can consider joining and can plan to stay within the organization for Sometime but i would suggest don't plan to stay here for more than 1-2 years if you are Joining at 3+ YOE.
WLB is not great as well as not that Bad overall WLB is okayish 60-70% People Stay till late night in the office.
HR will play lot of tricks to lowball you, just deny them diplomatically if they are not meeting your expectations. one of my friend did the same and last 12 days of notice period from his current organization my friend informed Sanvine that i got better offer almost 90% hike from my current salary which is close to 28 LPA Base and i will not be joining, then HR started saying lot of things you will have good exposure , learning opportunity bla bla bla.... finally he refused sandvine and joined with the new offer.
Problem is that: only the senior most people who are not capable enough and are here for more than 10 years are withdrawing huge salary and for mid level engineers (3+ YOE) they are looking for good candidates who can actually work hard but at the cost of pennies.
conclusion: give it least priority...
if you are a above average Software Engineer and making a switch you can expect the below salary in the market which would be a fair according to 2025 Standards. Standards may differ if you are watching this post after 2025.
3-4 Years: BASE: 24-30 LPA
4-7 Years: BASE: 32 - 48 LPA

Hi all!

🔹 Types of Design Rounds at Meta
According to the recruiter, there are two kinds of design interviews at Meta:

2. Product Architecture / Design – typically for Fullstack Engineers
Since I’m being considered for a Backend role, I’ll be getting the System Design round.

System Design:
“We expect you to demonstrate an understanding of low-level constraints and how they affect high-level goals. Talk through trade-offs and design choices.”
Topics they expect you to discuss include:
• Testability: Confidence in component correctness
• Usability: User experience and rapid evolution
• Extensibility: Ease of adapting over time
• Security: Resilience to attacks (DDoS, spoofing, etc.)
• Portability: Ability to run in different environments
• Availability: Failure handling
• Scalability: Handling growth
• Operational characteristics: Debugging and diagnostics
Example questions:
• Design a URL shortener
• Build Facebook chat
• Architect a global video distribution platform
⸻
Product Architecture / Design (for Fullstack roles) focuses more on:
• API and service design
• Client-server models
• Data models and protocols
• Balancing complexity and product flexibility
⸻

title: Top 10 System Design Interview Mistakes
content:
System design rounds often carry significant weight in onsite loops for mid- to senior-level roles. Even at SDE-1, interviewers want to see thoughtful trade-offs and clear architecture thinking. Avoiding these common pitfalls can dramatically improve your chances.
1. Skipping Requirement Clarification
Mistake: Jumping straight into drawing diagrams.
Why It’s Bad: You might build the wrong system.
Fix: Spend 2–3 minutes confirming functional (throughput, latency) and non‐functional (SLAs, scale) requirements. Ask questions like:
“What’s our target QPS?”
“How consistent must reads be?”
2. Over-Engineering from the Start
Mistake: Designing full microservices before tackling basics.
Why It’s Bad: You’ll run out of time and confuse the interviewer.
Fix: First propose a simple monolith or single‐service solution. Then iterate:
Single API server + relational DB
Add caching layer
Introduce partitioning or sharding
3. Neglecting Data Modeling
Mistake: Ignoring how data is stored—jumping straight to load balancers.
Why It’s Bad: You can’t discuss partition keys or index strategies later.
Fix: Sketch your database schema early. Discuss:
Table design (primary keys, foreign keys)
Indexes vs. full‐text search
SQL vs. NoSQL trade-offs
4. Failing to Address Failure Modes
Mistake: Assuming every component is 100% available.
Why It’s Bad: Real systems fail; you need resilience.
Fix: For each component, ask “What if it fails?” Then propose:
Circuit breakers
Retry policies with exponential backoff
Dead-letter queues
5. Ignoring Security & Privacy
Mistake: Leaving out authentication, authorization, or data encryption.
Why It’s Bad: Security is non-negotiable in interviews and production.
Fix: Explicitly call out:
OAuth or token‐based auth flow
TLS for data in transit
Encryption at rest
6. Overlooking Monitoring & Metrics
Mistake: Finishing the design without thinking about observability.
Why It’s Bad: You can’t ensure SLAs without monitoring.
Fix: Propose metrics and dashboards:
QPS, latency percentiles (p95/p99)
Error rates, number of timeouts
Health checks and alerting
7. Rushing Through Caching Strategies
Mistake: Saying “we’ll cache” without specifying patterns.
Why It’s Bad: Interviewers want depth on cache invalidation, cache stampede.
Fix: Describe:
Cache-aside vs. write-through vs. write-back
Expiration policies (TTL, LRU)
Stampede protection (mutex, request coalescing)
8. Forgetting Data Consistency Models
Mistake: Assuming strong consistency everywhere.
Why It’s Bad: You might block high-throughput use cases unnecessarily.
Fix: Discuss consistency trade-offs:
Strong vs. eventual consistency
When read-your-writes or monotonic reads matter
Use cases for quorum reads/writes
9. Not Time-Boxing Your Discussion
Mistake: Spending the entire time on one component.
Why It’s Bad: You might never cover scaling, monitoring, or failover.
Fix: Allocate rough time:
5 min requirements
10 min high-level design
10 min deep dive (pick one component)
5 min scaling, monitoring, wrap-up
10. Skipping Trade-Off Conversations
Mistake: Presenting a single “perfect” solution.
Why It’s Bad: Interviewers want to see how you evaluate options.
Fix: For each key decision, explicitly compare alternatives:
SQL vs. NoSQL: latency vs. consistency
Monolith vs. microservices: simplicity vs. maintainability
CDN vs. origin server: cost vs. performance
Final Tips
Practice End-to-End: Design a service start to finish in 20 minutes on a whiteboard or Excalidraw.
Get Feedback: Record your mock interviews and note missing sections.
Stay Conversational: Talk through assumptions and trade-offs as you draw.

im gonna stay annonymous
Part 2 – The Rounds, The Standards, The Pressure
After getting that long-awaited email from Google HR, I had my initial screening — and I’d say I played all the right cards, because I cleared it and moved to the next step.
Soon, I was invited to an orientation call, where they broke down the entire interview process:
1 Telephonic Round: Focused on DSA/Coding (Eliminatory)
Onsite Rounds (4 total, if you pass):
2 DSA rounds
1 Domain/DSA round (based on your experience)
1 Googliness round (behavioral)
Then came the telephonic round — the first big test. One thing to know about Google interviews: they often keep questions vague on purpose. Not to confuse you, but to observe how well you communicate, how you break down problems, and how deeply you think.
📌 Golden Rule for Google Interviews:
Read the problem multiple times.
Ask clarifying questions.
Don’t rush into coding.
They want clean, well-thought-out solutions — not quick fixes.
My telephonic round had two tree-based questions:
One was centered on Inorder Traversal.
The other seemed like a follow-up, but turned out to be completely independent — testing if I could recognize the difference and push back if needed.
I proposed alternate and optimized solutions to both — and that helped me stand out.
A week later, I got a call from HR: I passed! They asked for my availability for onsite interviews — five potential days. I agreed. My interviews were scheduled on four consecutive days, which was incredibly stressful.
In the week leading up, I was grinding hard on everything I ever struggled with:
KMP, Convex Hull, Segment Trees, and more. I was mentally exhausted, constantly questioning if I’d even make it.
Onsite Round 1
A two-pointer problem with precomputation, related to subarray sums.
Onsite Round 2
A recursive tree problem involving contiguous and isolated identical values.
Onsite Round 3
The interviewer didn’t show up, so it got postponed a week.
When it finally happened, it was a stack-based question involving bracket matching and equation simplification.
Googliness Round
Focused on behavioral aspects — leadership, pressure handling, communication, and ethics.
All these rounds, back to back, were mentally draining. I had panic attacks. At one point, I was literally crying and breathless during the interview, but somehow — I held it together.
I cleared 3 out of 4 rounds. The one I missed? The one where anxiety truly got the best of me.
Still, HR told me that passing 2 was enough, and I’d done really well — so they pushed me forward. I went through team matching and everything was going well... until it wasn’t.
Hiring Committee backed out , probably concerned about the one failed round, scheduled 2 more DSA interviews to be safe 🙃.
Then began a 2-month delay full of reschedules and uncertainty.
Onsite Round 4
An array-based problem involving greedy strategy, prefix sums, and hashmap balancing.
It felt like solving a complex necklace arrangement problem — but the question was poorly worded, and the test cases were brutal. I was on the edge the whole time.
Onsite Round 5
Thankfully, this was a Leetcode contest problem I’d solved 2 months ago and was daily problem a week ago 😉. The follow-up was the same, but seeing me solve quickly, the interviewer got suspicious and gave me a third follow-up.
Luckily, I had my heap, two-pointer, and binary search strategies ready — and nailed it.
After those two final rounds, I felt hopeful but also scared.
What if they think I cheated?
What if they drop me now?
I had worked too hard and come too far.
But the truth is — the real game is in how you communicate.
How you shape the problem, how you ask the right questions, how you structure your thoughts.
There were moments I was running out of time, but because my approach was solid and I picked the right data structures, I was given a pass.
A week later, HR called:
“It’s all positive! …But your matched team has moved on.”
Back to team-matching — again.
Two more weeks. Two more screenings.
Finally… I found my team.
In the next part, I’ll share how the salary negotiation unfolded, along with the perks, benefits, and everything else that came with the offer — stay tuned!

title: Resume vs. LinkedIn - Which Actually Got Me More Interviews?
content:
Hey everyone,
I recently ran an experiment to find out which channel—career portal resume submissions or LinkedIn outreach—yielded better results. Over two months, I sent out 200 applications split evenly between the two methods. Here’s what happened and what I learned.
The Numbers
Channel Applications Sent Responses Received Interviews Scheduled Offers Received
Career Portal 100 8 3 0
LinkedIn Outreach 100 45 12 2
Key Observations
Response Rate:
Career Portal: 8%
LinkedIn Outreach: 45%
Quality of Replies:
Career Portal replies were mostly generic (“Thanks, we’ll get back to you.”)
LinkedIn replies led to meaningful conversations (~75% converted to phone screens)
Interview Ratio:
Career Portal → Interview: 3%
LinkedIn → Interview: 12%
Offers:
Both offers I received came through LinkedIn outreach.
What Worked on LinkedIn
Personalized Messages: I referenced a recent blog post or product launch in each note.
Clear “Ask”: I asked for a specific 15-minute call to discuss how my experience could help their team.
Timed Follow-Up: I sent one polite follow-up after five business days if there was no reply.
How I Improved My Resume
Even after rewriting my resume, portal submissions lagged behind LinkedIn. Changes I made included:
Quantifying Impact: Changed vague bullets (e.g., “Built APIs”) to specifics (e.g., “Built and maintained 12 REST APIs handling 1M+ daily requests”).
Keyword Alignment: Matched terminology from the job description to pass ATS filters.
Cleaner Layout: Adopted a one-column design with bold section headers and consistent formatting.

title: Amazon OA Walkthrough: 3 Problems, 90 Minutes, Here’s My Code
content:
Hey everyone,
I just wrapped up Amazon’s SDE-2 Online Assessment and thought I’d share a step-by-step recap—the exact problems, my solutions (with edge-case handling!), and what I’d change if I did it again. Hopefully this helps anyone on the fence about how to tackle that dreaded 90-minute timer.
The Setup
Duration: 90 minutes
Environment: HackerRank-style editor, no external libraries
Problems:
Medium: Merge k Sorted Lists
Hard: Word Ladder II
Medium: Count of Smaller Numbers After Self
I paced myself about 30 minutes per problem, leaving a few minutes at the end of each for quick review.
1️ Problem 1: Merge k Sorted Lists (Medium)
Prompt (summarized):
You have k linked lists, each sorted ascending. Merge them into one sorted list and return its head.
My Approach:
Use a min-heap keyed by node value.
Push the head of each non-empty list into the heap.
Repeatedly pop the smallest node, append it to the result, and if that node has a next, push next into the heap.
import heapq

def mergeKLists(lists):
    heap = []
    for idx, node in enumerate(lists):
        if node:
            heapq.heappush(heap, (node.val, idx, node))
    dummy = ListNode(0)
    tail = dummy

    while heap:
        val, idx, node = heapq.heappop(heap)
        tail.next = node
        tail = tail.next
        if node.next:
            heapq.heappush(heap, (node.next.val, idx, node.next))

    return dummy.next
Edge Cases & Lessons:
Identical values: I included idx in the heap tuple to avoid tie issues.
Empty input list: Checked if node before pushing.
Could’ve been 3–4 minutes faster by pre-allocating the dummy and skipping the tuple index, but safe is better under pressure.
2️ Problem 2: Word Ladder II (Hard)
Prompt (summarized):
Given beginWord, endWord, and a wordList, return all shortest transformation sequences from beginWord to endWord. Each step must change one letter and land in wordList.
My Approach:
BFS to build a graph of shortest-level connections.
DFS/backtracking from beginWord to endWord, following only edges that move to the next level.
from collections import defaultdict, deque

def findLadders(begin, end, wordList):
    wordSet = set(wordList)
    if end not in wordSet:
        return []

    # Build adjacency by BFS levels
    levels = {begin: 0}
    graph = defaultdict(list)
    queue = deque([begin])

    while queue:
        word = queue.popleft()
        for i in range(len(word)):
            for c in 'abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz':
                nxt = word[:i] + c + word[i+1:]
                if nxt in wordSet:
                    if nxt not in levels:
                        levels[nxt] = levels[word] + 1
                        queue.append(nxt)
                    if levels[nxt] == levels[word] + 1:
                        graph[word].append(nxt)

    # Backtrack all shortest paths
    res = []
    def dfs(path):
        if path[-1] == end:
            res.append(path[:])
            return
        for nxt in graph[path[-1]]:
            dfs(path + [nxt])

    dfs([begin])
    return res
What I’d improve:
I got TLE on large inputs because I regenerated all 26-letter possibilities each time. Pre-computing generic patterns (h*t, ho*, etc.) would be faster.
3️ Problem 3: Count of Smaller Numbers After Self (Medium)
Prompt (summarized):
For each element in nums, count how many elements to its right are smaller. Return the list of counts.
My Approach:
Used a Fenwick Tree (Binary Indexed Tree) on the compressed ranks of the values.
Traverse from right to left, query the BIT for how many have rank < current rank, then update the BIT at current rank.
def countSmaller(nums):
    # Coordinate compression
    sorted_unique = sorted(set(nums))
    rank = {v: i+1 for i, v in enumerate(sorted_unique)}
    size = len(sorted_unique)
    BIT = [0] * (size + 1)

    def update(i):
        while i <= size:
            BIT[i] += 1
            i += i & -i

    def query(i):
        s = 0
        while i > 0:
            s += BIT[i]
            i -= i & -i
        return s

    res = []
    for x in reversed(nums):
        r = rank[x]
        res.append(query(r - 1))
        update(r)
    return res[::-1]
Key Points:
Compression handles negatives/large values.
Fenwick guarantees O(n log n).
What I’d Do Differently
Time allocation: I spent 35 min on Word Ladder II and got TLE. Next time, I’d allocate only 25 min to it and move on.
Edge-case checklist: I missed testing [] and single-element inputs on the first problem—would write simple asserts before coding.
Quick skimming: I’d note “constraints: wordList up to 5 k words” and opt for pattern-based adjacency pre-compute immediately.

Views on the market: The market is tough right now — even one weak round can lead to rejection or down-leveling. That being said, good prep still goes a long way. Roles are fewer, but companies continue to hire top talent.
Tips and strategies:
One notable shift I observed was the reduced emphasis on traditional LeetCode-style problems. For example, companies like Samsara and Stripe didn’t include any such rounds. The focus has moved towards medium-level coding problems with more weight on how you approach the problem, your code structure, modularity, edge case handling, and overall discussion. Only Meta and Google still stick to hardcore LC-style questions.
For System Design, senior roles now expect staff-level depth. And don’t ignore the behavioral rounds — they’re critical. A weak showing here can lead to down-leveling, regardless of technical performance.

title: The No-Nonsense Guide to Mastering LeetCode for Your Dream Tech Job
content:
Hey folks,
I’ve been knee-deep in LeetCode for months, prepping for interviews and trying to level up my coding game. Along the way, I’ve talked to friends who’ve scored jobs at places like Amazon, Apple, and smaller startups, and I’ve had my fair share of “ugh, why didn’t I see that?” moments. If you’re feeling swamped by LeetCode or wondering how to prep without turning into a coding zombie, I’ve got you covered. Here’s a straightforward guide to making LeetCode your ally, not your enemy, written like we’re just chatting over a burger.
Why LeetCode Matters (But Isn’t Your Entire Life)
LeetCode is a big piece of the puzzle for software engineering interviews, especially at product-based companies like Google or Meta. It’s not just about banging out code—it’s about showing you can untangle a problem, think clearly, and write something that works without a million bugs, even when you’re nervous. But here’s the deal: LeetCode is only part of the picture. Companies also want to see your projects, hear how you work with others, and know you’re not just a code machine. So, let’s talk about how to prep efficiently and still have time for, you know, life.
My Key Takeaways for LeetCode Success
Here’s what I’ve learned from my own grind, plus some wisdom from friends who’ve been through the interview gauntlet:
Go for Depth, Not Just Numbers
When I started, I thought I had to solve 400 problems to be “ready.” Turns out, that’s a recipe for burnout. After about 120 problems, I was mostly redoing the same ideas in different flavors.
Aim for 60–80 well-chosen problems that cover the essentials: arrays, strings, linked lists, binary trees, graphs, dynamic programming, and two-pointer techniques.
Stick to medium problems—they’re the bread and butter of most interviews. Add a handful of hards if you’re aiming for FAANG or similar.
Check out LeetCode’s “Top 100 Liked Questions” or filter by company (like “Microsoft” or “Adobe”) to focus on what’s relevant.
Get the Logic, Don’t Just Copy-Paste
Early on, I’d get stuck and rush to the solution tab, thinking I’d magically “get it.” Big nope. You need to wrestle with the problem to actually learn.
Give yourself 15–20 minutes to think before peeking at hints. Ask: What’s the input? What’s the output? Can I solve it the slow way first?
Jot down your thoughts—on paper, a whiteboard, or even a random napkin. It’s crazy how much clearer things get when you map it out.
After solving, hit up the discussion tab. You’ll find clever tricks or edge cases you didn’t consider.
Prep for the Interviewer’s Follow-Ups
Interviewers love to spice things up with questions like, “Can you optimize this?” or “What if the input is a million rows?” You’ve got to be ready to adapt.
Practice explaining your solution’s time and space complexity in simple terms, like you’re telling a friend.
Know how to shift from a clunky brute-force approach to something leaner, like using a hash set instead of a double loop.
Learn patterns like sliding windows, DFS/BFS, or binary search—they’re like shortcuts that unlock tons of problems.
Practice Like It’s the Real Deal
LeetCode’s timer is a great way to mimic interview pressure. Set a 30–45-minute limit per problem to get used to thinking on your feet.
Try mock interviews on platforms like Pramp or Interviewing.io. It’s awkward at first, but it’s gold for building confidence.
Talk through your solution out loud, even if it’s just to your cat. It’ll make explaining your thought process in interviews feel natural.
Keep Track of Your Progress
I started a simple Google Sheet to log my problems: topic, difficulty, link to my solution, and “what I screwed up.” It’s like a personal coach for spotting weak spots.
Revisit problems you struggled with every couple of weeks. You’ll be amazed at how much easier they feel.
Take a second to pat yourself on the back when you nail a tough one—it keeps the motivation up.
Bonus Tips to Shine Bright
Build one solid project with clean code and a nice README. It can impress recruiters more than a high LeetCode streak.
Reach out for referrals. A quick LinkedIn message to someone at the company can get your resume to the top of the pile.
Don’t sleep on behavioral interviews. Prep stories for questions like “Tell me about a time you failed” to show you’re human and learn from mistakes.
If LeetCode’s sucking your soul, take a break and study system design or CS fundamentals. Variety keeps you sane.
Your Starter Plan
If you’re wondering where to begin, here’s a quick roadmap:
Week 1: Knock out 10–15 easy problems to get comfortable. Focus on arrays and strings.
Weeks 2–3: Tackle 25–30 mediums across graphs, trees, and dynamic programming. Learn one new pattern, like two-pointers.
Week 4: Try 5–10 hards and revisit your toughest problems. Do a mock interview with a friend.
Keep it going: Solve 2–3 problems a day, explain one solution out loud, and polish your portfolio.
My Thoughts
LeetCode isn’t about being a coding wizard—it’s about showing you can solve problems, write solid code, and keep your cool. You don’t need to be perfect; you just need to be prepared. Every problem you crack is a step closer to that “You’re hired!” email. Stay consistent, don’t beat yourself up over mistakes, and you’ll get there.

As a developer, especially one working with hardware interfaces, robotics, AR/VR, or in tech labs with physical components, eye protection isn’t just for electricians or factory workers.
Whether you're prototyping hardware, working in IoT labs, or doing fieldwork that involves electronics, safety glasses with prescription lenses or blue-light protection are essential.
I’ve seen colleagues suffer minor eye injuries just from soldering or battery pack incidents. Don’t assume that being a “coder” means you’re immune to workplace hazards.

title: Rejected Before the Final Step — After Months of Struggle
content:
After 10+ grueling months and applying to over 1,000 jobs, I finally thought I was close.
I had cleared all the preliminary rounds. The recruiter even asked me to prep for the Hiring Manager (HM) round, scheduled for tomorrow. For the first time in a long time, I felt a flicker of real hope — this time, it seemed real. Who fails the HM call anyway, right? I thought I was past the hardest part.
But today(10 mins ago of now), out of nowhere, I received an email: they had decided to move forward with another candidate. No interview. No conversation. Just... done.
After months of stress, silence, ghosting, and self-doubt, this opportunity felt like a light at the end of a very long tunnel. Now, it feels like the tunnel just collapsed.
I won’t name the company, but it was one of the top-tier places where just getting a foot in the door is a battle in itself.
Right now, I just feel like a complete failure.
I think I need a break before I can start grinding again. This cycle is brutal.
Just venting here. I don’t have many people to lean on.

title: 40 LPA? Fulfil HR call experience
content:
Hey Coders,
I recently had an interesting experience during a screening call that I wanted to share for perspective.
Role: Senior SDE
CTC mentioned on the job portal: ₹30–40 LPA
My YOE: 2.7 years
Current CTC: ₹7 LPA
Current Designation: Senior SDE at a product-based company
During the call, the recruiter asked about my expected CTC. I responded honestly, saying that as a candidate, I’d obviously aim higher, so I quoted ₹40 LPA. It might seem unrealistic to some, but from my perspective, here’s why I believe it’s justified:
I’ve been solving LeetCode problems daily for the past year, without missing a single day.
I completed an expensive system design course (you can guess which one xD) to strengthen my architecture skills.
Due to my contributions at work, I was promoted to Senior SDE within a year.
I believe my lower current CTC is primarily because I started my career with lower pay, not because of a lack of skill or value.
The recruiter asked, "Considering your skill set, how are you sure about expecting 40 LPA?"
In my mind, I thought — this is just the first HR call; shouldn’t technical assessments come next?
I asked for clarification: “Are you referring to my resume or something else?”
He replied, “I’m talking about your resume and your communication skills.”
At that point, I didn’t really have a comeback about communication skills — I had nothing to say.
He also mentioned, "Just because the role title matches your current designation doesn’t mean you’re a fit for the role."
The role required experience with Django, which I haven’t worked with directly. However, I do have experience with Spring Boot and Node.js, and I don’t believe Django would be a big leap. I said I could pick it up in a month.
He responded, “We have people with 10 years of experience working on Django. And you think you can learn it in one month?”
After that, for every response, he kept saying, "I am not convinced with your answer."
I still think I can get a better opportunity than this, but I felt he got aggressive during the call, which wasn’t necessary.

title: Finding the Closest Person on a Number Line – Simple and Efficient Approach
content:
Greedy Algorithm / Math / Distance Calculation
Problem Summary:
We are given three positions on a number line:
x: Position of Person 1.
y: Position of Person 2.
z: Position of Person 3 (the destination point).
Person 1 and Person 2 both move towards Person 3 at the same speed, and we need to determine which person reaches Person 3 first. If both arrive at the same time, we return 0. Otherwise, we return 1 for Person 1 or 2 for Person 2, depending on who arrives first.
Approach:
The problem is quite simple and involves calculating the absolute distance from each person to Person 3 and comparing those distances.
Calculate the Distance: We can calculate the distance from Person 1 to Person 3 as abs(x - z), and similarly, calculate the distance for Person 2 with abs(y - z).
Comparison:
If the distance for Person 1 is smaller than that of Person 2, return 1 (meaning Person 1 reaches first).
If the distance for Person 2 is smaller than that of Person 1, return 2.
If both distances are the same, return 0 (indicating they reach at the same time).
This approach ensures an O(1) time complexity, as we only need to perform a few constant-time operations.
Code Implementation:
class Solution {
public:
int findClosest(int x, int y, int z) {
int dist1 = abs(x - z); // Distance from Person 1 to Person 3
int dist2 = abs(y - z); // Distance from Person 2 to Person 3
    if (dist1 < dist2) return 1;      // Person 1 reaches first
    else if (dist2 < dist1) return 2; // Person 2 reaches first
    else return 0;                   // Both reach at the same time
}
};
Time Complexity:
The time complexity of the solution is O(1) because we are performing constant-time operations (absolute difference and comparisons).
Space Complexity:
The space complexity is O(1) as we are only using a fixed amount of extra space to store distances.
Quote: "The simplest solutions are often the most effective ones."
Link: LeetCode Problem 3516 - Find Closest Person
Edge Cases:
Both at the Same Distance:
Example: x = 1, y = 5, z = 3
In this case, both Person 1 and Person 2 are at the same distance from Person 3, so the result should be 0.
One Person Already at the Position:
Example: x = 2, y = 5, z = 5
Here, Person 2 is already at position z, and Person 1 has to move. The expected output is 2.
Both Positions Are the Same:
Example: x = 2, y = 2, z = 2
Both persons are already at the destination, so the result should be 0.

title: most important graph problems for FAANG
content:
Google’s Favorite Graph Questions
Course Schedule (Topological Sort)
Number of Provinces (Union Find)
Network Delay Time (Dijkstra’s Algorithm)
Longest Increasing Path in a Matrix (DP + DFS)
🟠 Amazon’s Favorite Graph Questions
Clone Graph (BFS/DFS)
Redundant Connection (Union Find)
All Paths from Source to Target (Backtracking)
🔵 Meta (Facebook)’s Favorite Graph Questions
Course Schedule II (Topological Sort)
Critical Connections in a Network (Tarjan’s Algorithm)
Evaluate Division (Weighted BFS)
🟢 Microsoft’s Favorite Graph Questions
Find if Path Exists in Graph (BFS)
Most Stones Removed with Same Row or Column (Union Find)
Longest Cycle in a Graph (Cycle Detection)
🟣 Uber/Bloomberg’s Favorite Graph Questions
Network Delay Time (Dijkstra’s Algorithm)
Number of Provinces (Union Find)
Clone Graph (OOP + Traversal)
If the problem mentions "order/dependencies" → Think TopoSort.
If cycle detection is needed → Use DFS with recursion_stack.
If all possible orders are needed → Backtracking + BFS.
📌 Key Notes:
Google loves Topological Sort + Dijkstra.
Amazon focuses on Union Find + Graph Traversal.
Meta asks advanced graph algorithms (Tarjan’s, Weighted BFS).
Microsoft prefers Cycle Detection + Union Find.
Uber/Bloomberg repeats Google’s favorites (Dijkstra, Union Find).

Top 10 Two Pointers Problems for Interviews
Two Sum II - Input Array Is Sorted (Easy) — Google, Amazon, Microsoft
3Sum (Medium) — Facebook, Amazon, Google
Trapping Rain Water (Hard) — Amazon, Google, Microsoft
Container With Most Water (Medium) — Amazon, Google, Facebook
Linked List Cycle (Easy) — Amazon, Microsoft, Bloomberg
Remove Nth Node From End of List (Medium) — Amazon, Facebook, Google
Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters (Medium) — Google, Amazon, Microsoft
Minimum Size Subarray Sum (Medium) — Amazon, Google, Facebook
Merge Sorted Array (Easy) — Amazon, Microsoft, Adobe
Valid Palindrome (Easy) — Facebook, Google, Amazon
Key Patterns to Master:
Opposite Ends: Sum/compare pairs (e.g., Two Sum, 3Sum).
When to Use Opposite Ends?
The input is sorted (or can be sorted).
You need to find pairs (e.g., two numbers that sum to a target).
You need to reverse, partition, or compare elements from both ends.
You need to maximize/minimize a value (e.g., maximum area, minimum swaps).
Approach:
Initialize Two Pointers:
left = 0 (start of the array)
right = n - 1 (end of the array)
Loop Until Pointers Meet (left ≤ right)
Compare arr[left] and arr[right].
Depending on the problem, move one or both pointers inward.
Terminate When Pointers Cross
Stop when left > right (all possible pairs processed).
Sliding Window: Subarray/substring problems.
When to Use Sliding Window?
Subarray/Substring Problems :
Find the longest/shortest subarray with a condition.
Calculate sums, averages, or counts in a fixed-size window.
Optimization Problems:
Maximize/minimize a value (e.g., max sum, min length).
Problems with Constraints:
"Find a substring with at most K distinct characters."
"Find the smallest subarray with a sum ≥ target."
Types of Sliding Window
Fixed-Length Window ( constant )
Apporach :
Compute the sum of the first K elements.
Slide the window by adding the next element and subtracting the leftmost element.
variable length ( Window size changes dynamically based on a condition.)
Apporach :
Use two pointers (left, right) to represent the window.
Expand the window (right++) until the condition is met.
Shrink the window (left++) until the condition is violated.
Unique/Distinct Characters
Apporach :
Track character frequency in a hashmap.
Shrink window when len(hashmap) > K.
Counting Subarrays with a Condition
Apporach :
Expand right and multiply product.
Shrink left if product ≥ K.
Count subarrays as right - left + 1.
Slow/Fast: Cycle detection, midpoint finding.
Merging: Sorted arrays or linked lists.

title: Software Dev Engineer FTE position at Amazon Audible
content:
🚀 Amazon SDE New Grad 2025 – Final Onsite (Virtual) Interview Experience
I recently completed the final virtual onsite interviews for the Software Development Engineer (SDE) – Full-Time Role through Amazon University Talent Acquisition, and I’d like to share my full experience for those preparing for similar roles.
📍 Interview Details:
🗓️ Date: April 15, 2025
🏢 Hosted from Oregon (Virtual from East Coast, USA)
💻 Platform: Amazon Chime + LiveCode
🧑‍💻 Format: 3 Interviews (1 hour each), back-to-back with a 30-minute break between round 2 and 3
✅ Round 1 – Leadership Principles (Behavioral Only)
Entirely focused on Amazon’s LPs
Key questions included:
"How do you handle missing deadlines?"
"Tell me about a time you took initiative on a task outside your role."
The interviewer was friendly and focused on depth of examples using the STAR method.
✅ Round 2 – Pure Coding (DSA)
Interviewer: SDM (Software Development Manager)
Two questions:
Q1: Variation of Binary Tree Level Order Traversal (Easy) — return levels using a linked list format
Q2: Medium-level Amazon K-Winner Lottery Problem — Weighted random winner based on customer purchase amount (e.g., 1=1chance,10 = 10 chances)
I fully solved the first question. I struggled a bit on the second but communicated my approach.
The interviewer was very understanding and helped me stay on track with helpful clarifications.
✅ Round 3 – Mixed: Behavioral + Coding
~30 min behavioral:
"Tell me about a time you worked under pressure."
"Have you ever missed a deadline? What did you learn?"
~30 min coding:
Word Search in a 2D Grid — Classic DFS with backtracking problem (LeetCode Medium)
Interviewer was calm, gave hints when appropriate, and made the session very engaging.
🧠 Preparation Summary:
DSA Practice: Blind 75, Top Amazon-tagged LeetCode problems
Key Topics: Arrays, Strings, BFS/DFS, Trees, HashMaps, Backtracking
Behavioral: Deep STAR stories from real experience: CES (Spring Boot APIs, ML forecasting), IoasiZ (CI/CD pipelines), Aramark (AWS scripts), and Harshwardhan (Networking automation)
Mock Rounds: Peer interviews + STAR reviews
Fun Fact: Mentioned my use of Audible and books I listened to: Atomic Habits, The Next Conversation, Fearless, and even How to Answer Interview Questions by Peggy McKee — great icebreaker!
💡 Key Learnings:
Communicate clearly even if you’re stuck — your thought process matters.
Leadership Principles are deeply woven into the process — prepare personalized STAR stories.
Interviewers care more about how you think and learn, not just about passing every test case.
Stay calm, own your story, and show growth.
🙌 Final Note:
This was my first full SDE onsite-style experience and I walked away learning a lot about Amazon’s culture — leadership, mentorship, and high standards.
If you're on a similar journey, feel free to reach out. Happy to exchange notes and prep tips!

title: Software Engineer I - Interview Experience for Nike (Bangalore Onsite)
content:
Hey folks,
🧾 Offer Details:
Company: Nike
Role: Software Engineer I (SWE I)
Location: Bangalore
Experience: 1.3 Years
(Current: SDET at service based MNC with fullstack & AI agent training exposure)
CTC: ₹14 LPA
(₹11.4 LPA Fixed + ₹1.1 LPA Performance Bonus + Other Benefits)
In-hand: ~₹95K/month (pre-tax)
Joining Date: 16th June 2025
I recently got selected for the SWE I role at Nike (Bangalore) and wanted to share my complete interview experience. For context, I have 1.3 years of full-time experience (excluding internship). All three rounds were conducted onsite in a single day with direct elimination after each round.
📩 Initial Process:
Got an email from the recruiter.
Shared my resume and got shortlisted.
Within 3 days, I was invited for the onsite interview at the Nike office in Bangalore.
🧠 Round 1: Technical Interview (Backend Focus – Node.js, Express)
This round focused on my backend development experience and understanding of architecture:
Started with questions about my current work and personal projects.
Moved to backend concepts:
Explained HTTP methods: GET, POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE.
Asked to write controller logic on the whiteboard (syntax wasn’t the focus — clarity, structure, and problem approach were key).
Questions around MVC architecture, database integration, API flows, and route-controller design.
Asked about async/await, what happens without using await, and handling asynchronous flows.
Also touched on personal project implementation details.
✅ Cleared the round and moved to the second.
🧠 Round 2: Design-Oriented Technical Interview
This round leaned more towards design and architecture thinking:
I was given a system to design and asked how I’d break it down.
I mentioned that while I’m still learning system design in depth, I have a high-level understanding of tech stack planning and component breakdown.
We discussed backend design using Node.js, Express.js, and MongoDB.
Some follow-up questions on hashing and file comparison came up too.
✅ Cleared this round as well.
🧠 Round 3: Hiring Manager Round
This was a mix of technical depth and behavioral assessment:
Walked through my current organization work and personal projects.
React-related technical questions with follow-ups.
Switched to backend: scenario-based questions on performance and optimization.
Assessed problem-solving and communication skills through follow-up challenges.
Ended with behavioral and situational questions.
He also shared Nike’s team ethics and culture before wrapping up.
And finally… ✅ Got selected after the 3rd round, officially starting my journey as an SWE I at Nike.

What java version version do you use

List of Emp POJO with name, id etc. filter it via streams where name starts with your first name

Tell me about the different map versions you know in java

How does a hashmap works internally

hash collision (chaining, open addressing, double hashing)
again asked about chaining
mentioned a LL may be used

what version of springboot do you use

loose coupling, easy testing & mocking, cyclicity managed by sboot and singleton hence less space

if a prototype bean is autowired inside inside singleton bean, would it act like prototype?

title: 2140. Solving Questions With Brainpower
content:
Explanation:
1, Define dp[i] as the maximum points we can get starting from question i.
2. Iterate in reverse (from last question to first) because each decision depends on future questions.
Compute take and skip:
Take: Solve question i, earn points[i], and jump to i + brainpower + 1.
Skip: Ignore question i and move to i + 1.
Transition Formula:
dp[i]=max(take,skip)
Return dp[0] as the answer.
. Time & Space Complexity:
Time Complexity:
O(n) → We process each question once.
Space Complexity:
O(n) → Uses a DP array.
Python Code
class Solution(object):
def mostPoints(self, questions):
"""
:type questions: List[List[int]]
:rtype: int
"""
n = len(questions)
dp = [0] * (n + 1)

    for i in range(n - 1, -1, -1):
        points, brainpower = questions[i]
        next_question = i + brainpower + 1
        take = points + (dp[next_question] if next_question < n else 0)
        skip = dp[i + 1]
        dp[i] = max(take, skip)

    return dp[0]

title: Burnt Out and Stuck in Job Search FOMO
content:
I don’t know who needs to hear this, but job hunting is exhausting. Like, soul-crushing, "why am I even doing this?" exhausting. I’ve sent out over 1,000 applications in the past 10 months. You read that right—one thousand. Tailored resumes, cover letters, LinkedIn updates, networking emails. And you know what I’ve got to show for it? 3 interviews. Just 3.
I’m a middle-class guy working a not-so-great job that barely covers the bills. I dream of landing a high-paying role where I can finally breathe—pay off debts, help my family, maybe even save for something nice. But every rejection feels like a punch to the gut. Worse, sometimes there’s no rejection at all—just silence. Ghosted by recruiters after pouring hours into perfecting my application.
And then there’s the FOMO (Fear of Missing Out). You know what I mean—scrolling through LinkedIn and seeing people announce their shiny new jobs at top companies while you’re stuck refreshing your inbox for any response. It’s like everyone else cracked some secret code to success that I missed. So, I keep applying to everything—every role, every industry—hoping something sticks. But deep down, I know this approach isn’t working. It’s just making me feel more lost.
I’m burnt out. Completely drained. Some days, I stare at my laptop and wonder if it’s even worth it anymore. But quitting isn’t an option—I have to keep going. For my family, for myself.
If you’re in the same boat, just know you’re not alone. This grind is brutal, but maybe sharing our struggles can help us feel a little less isolated.
Have you faced job search burnout or FOMO? How do you keep going when it feels like the world is moving forward without you? I could really use some advice right now.
#OpenToWork #JobSearchBurnout #CareerFOMO

title: Can You Solve a private Contest Question in C in 10 Minutes?
content:
Time limit per test: 1 second
Memory limit per test: 256 megabytes
Problem Statement:
The end of the school year is near and Ms. Manana, the teacher, will soon have to say goodbye to yet another class. She decided to prepare a goodbye present for her n students and give each of them a jigsaw puzzle (which, as Wikipedia states, is a tiling puzzle that requires the assembly of numerous small, often oddly shaped, interlocking, and tessellating pieces).
The shop assistant told the teacher that there are m puzzles in the shop, but they might differ in difficulty and size. Specifically, the first jigsaw puzzle consists of f1 pieces, the second one consists of f2 pieces, and so on.
Ms. Manana doesn't want to upset the children, so she decided that the difference between the numbers of pieces in her presents must be as small as possible. Let A be the number of pieces in the largest puzzle that the teacher buys, and B be the number of pieces in the smallest such puzzle. She wants to choose n puzzles such that A − B is as small as possible. Help the teacher and find the least possible value of A − B.
Input:
The first line contains space-separated integers n and m (2 ≤ n ≤ m ≤ 50).
The second line contains m space-separated integers f1, f2, ..., fm (4 ≤ fi ≤ 1000) — the quantities of pieces in the puzzles sold in the shop.
Output:
Print a single integer — the least possible difference the teacher can obtain.
Example:
Input:
4 6
10 12 10 7 5 22
Output:
5
Explanation:
The class has 4 students. The shop sells 6 puzzles. If Ms. Manana buys the first four puzzles consisting of 10, 12, 10, and 7 pieces correspondingly, then the difference between the sizes of the largest and the smallest puzzle will be equal to 5. It is impossible to obtain a smaller difference. Note that the teacher can also buy puzzles 1, 3, 4, and 5 to obtain the difference 5.
Private Contest:
This problem is part of a private coding contest, designed to test your problem-solving skills in C. The challenge focuses on array manipulation and sorting techniques. Try to solve it in 10 minutes!

content:

Technical Interview - Round 2(Same day as round 1)

A 1-hour deep dive into my current work, covering technical contributions, challenges, and problem-solving approach.
Offer & Background

It's another beautiful day on Farmer John's farm.
After Farmer John arrived at his farm, he counted n legs. It is known that only chickens and cows live on the farm, and a chicken has 2 legs while a cow has 4.
What is the minimum number of animals Farmer John can have on his farm assuming he counted the legs of all animals?
Input:
The first line contains a single integer t (1 ≤ t ≤ 10³) — the number of test cases.
Each test case contains an integer n (2 ≤ n ≤ 2 × 10³, n is even).
Output:
For each test case, output a single integer — the minimum number of animals on the farm.
Example:
Input:
3
2
6
8
Output:
1
2
2

title: Amazon Phone Screen for SDE III
content:
Just got done with my Interview yesterday. Definately did not expect how it actually turned out , Interviewer definately went all solo inventing his own interview style and questions. title: Apple ICT3 | Full-Stack Engineer | Interview to Offer | Cupertino
content:
How I got shortlisted
Apple hires very specifically for teams and filters by candidates who have highly relevant experience. An initial resume screen is performed by the recruiters and then final shorlist is done by Managers who look for good overlap in technical skills of the candidate and skills required for the role.
So it's really important to tailor the resume to the Job description for Apple.
Applied to about 10+ roles on the Apple Careers site, whose description overlapped with my experience.
Recruiter Call
About a month later, a recruiter reached out regarding one of the roles. This was for a Full Stack Engineer on an internal ML platform.
Shared my experience and was able to move ahead for a Hiring Manager Round.
Hiring Manager
A very candid discussion on why I chose the role, my relevant experience, why I would like to join, where I see myself, and why I chose Apple.
The conversation was very positive, and I knew I was moving to the next round
Technical rounds have a general similarity.
The problems were highly vague. They required me to ask the right questions to complete the problem definition and then start working on it.
They were very keen on clear communication and discussions.
Technical Phone Screen
Problem 1: A vote counter
Started with this vague problem statement and narrowed it down to this -
Build a class to read millions of votes from a ballot list and perform rank-based vote counting. Had to handle batching to solve for memory usage.
Problem 2: Given a Binary tree of 0's and 1's where the left node is the same as the parent and the right node is opposite to the parent, determine the value of the n'th node at l'th level.
I sketched out a sample tree and then proceeded to use recursion to arrive at the solution.
Onsite - 5 rounds
Coding 1
Problem: Given a set of characters, determine all English words that can be created.
Started the discussion on determining the inputs and outputs, the structure of the dictionary to validate against.
Built a trie with the dictionary list and tested every permutation of the characters.
Optimised it in a second approach by generating a HashSet for every anagram in the dictionary and checking against characters.
System Design
This was not a generic design round at all.
The interviewer was a very experienced person who had worked with Apple for over 10 years.
The round focused primarily on my experience. He picked each of my experiences and we discussed very deeply about my entire task. Why I picked it, what I did (sketched multiple diagrams for each question), how I measured performance, what I would do differently today.
Behavioral
This round was with a senior manager.
Question: Given the values of Apple, such as Deep expertise and Drive for Excellence, how have you showcased these in your career?
I started picking examples from my first job to my last job, highlighting the different lessons I had learnt - technical, cultural, and leadership.
Some key lessons I highlighted were -
Keeping it simple (KISS).
Don't jump to solutioning too soon.
Respect everyone's expertise.
Resolving conflicts.
Motivating team members.
Coding 2
**Problem 1: **Given a dataset, sample n items while maintaining the original probability distribution.
Very straightforward problem, the solution was to maintain the original counts and use random to sample.
**Problem 2: **Create a React component that can display 1M records.
The problem required slicing the data and displaying only records that would fit within the scroll section.
This is a classic React interview problem.
Practice Resource : https://www.greatfrontend.com/interviews/dashboard
Had practiced questions from here which made this really easy to solve.
Coding 3
Discussed my expertise in React. Then the interviewer drew a basic input UI and asked me to implement it.
I showcased skills such as breaking down the UI into components, creating a higher order component, using UseEffect, UseMemo, and UseRef for functionality.
Mailed the recruiter for feedback as I had just cleared Amazon and had made a decision soon.
After continuous follow-up for 4 days got positive feedback.
Took another 2 days for the verbal offer and another 4 days for the written offer.
Apparently, Apple startes interviewing for a role prior to receiving approval and requires 4 levels of signatures up to the VP level to roll out the offer.
So, anyone waiting on Apple, just keep following up as they as gonna take their own time!
Offer
I already had an offer from Amazon for SDE 2, and so the baseline was set.
Apple was NOT able to match my Amazon offer at IC3 level as I only had 4.5 YOE and didn't qualify for IC4 :(
Base: 175K
Stock: 33K / year
**Sign On: **20k
**Yearly Bonus: **7.5% = ~13k
1st Year TC: 241K
Amazon TC: 280K
Amazon Innterview - https://leetcode.com/discuss/post/6558499/amazon-interview-expereince-l5-seattle-b-vmpa/
I still chose Apple as I didn't want to move to Seattle and deal with Amazon Culture.
It took me 4 months and 72 interviews to land my first Offer after being laid off.
Just when all hopes were lost is when I landed 4 back-to-back offers and finally picked Apple!
Keep grinding people. Everything eventually works out.
Luck is as important as the hard work we put in. So, don't be discouraged if you are not getting callbacks or interviews are not converting. Its not your fault.
Stay positive!
Happy to answer any questions!

title: Amazon | SDE-1 | Bangalore (Offer)
content:
Education - Tier-2 College B.Tech CSE
I had an OA + 3 interview rounds (online)
December 2024 (last week) - Got a mail asking to apply for SDE-1 if I am interested. Since have applied to Amazon for summer internship before, they had my email ID.
January 2025 (third week) - Got the OA link (medium)
First Question (Easy) - It was a greedy question in which you needed to count the minimum health a player needs to survive.
Second question (Medium) - Sliding window + hashmap question.
After DSA, it had the behaviorial part.
February 2025 (Second week) - Got the mail saying that I passed the OA and interviews will be scheduled soon.
February 2025 (Third week) - First interview round ( LP+DSA)
Started with each other's introduction and then 10 mins of Leadership Principles. He asked me 2 DSA questions.
First question - Build a data structure which can insert, search, delete and get random element in O(1) time. There was a follow up asking what if there are duplicates in the input.
Second question - Find square root of a number. I gave basic binary search answer then he followed up asking what if we want the answer with say 8 place decimal precision.
Need to tell time and space complexity of all codes. Brownie points if you explain with a dry run as well.
February 2025 (last week) - Got a call for the second interview at 11:30 am saying they want to schedule it that day 2 pm.
Second Round (LP+DSA) - Started just like the first one with introduction and then 10 mins of Leadership Principles. He asked 2 DSA questions.
First question - You are given the starting and ending times for ML models. Each model used a GPU to run. 4 GPUs make up 1 CPU. Find the minimum number of CPUs needed to run all the models. Basically this problem was a variation of the minimum number of platforms question. I followed with the line sweep algorithm first then he asked what if the time intervals are given in decimals then I told him the sorting+two pointers method.
Second Question - You are given a matrix full of 'S' and 'O'. Any 'O' or cluster of 'O' that are not covered by S from all directions become 'S' as well. We have to return the final state of the matrix. Basically any 'O' and the 'O' connected to it become
'S' as they are not covered, so you run a DFS for all 'o' on the edges and convert them one by one to 'S'. The rest of the 'O' after the DFS stay as 'O' only as they are surrounded by 'S'
Gave time and space complexity for both codes and the interview said at the end of interview that I did well (bro made me blush). Got mail
for the Bar Raised round 2 hours later scheduled for the next day.
February 2025 (last week) - Round 3 (Bar Raiser)
Interview started with Introduction and then started the spamming of Leadership Principles.
• Tell me about a time when you worked on something outside your comfort zone.
• Tell me about a time when you got negative feedback from a higher up.
And a lot more follow ups and questions.
We had 10-15 mins left after this rapid fire of Lps so the interviewer asked if I wanted to chat or he can ask a question. I just told him to ask a question, bro started smirking.
Question - We are given inputs in the form of Username - Page visited. We have to return the three page sequence which has been visited the most number of times by users.
Input - ‹ User1 - P1, User2 - P2, User1 - P3, ....}
So imagine User 1 has visited pages in the
order P1-P3-P4- P2
User2 has visited in the order P3-P4-P2-P1 and so on.
The final answer will be P3-P4-P2.
I just used hashmaps to store counts of 3 page sequences user by user and finally returned the sequence with max count.
Gave time and space complexity and the dry run.
March 2025 (Third week) - Got a call from Amazon recruiter saying congrats and they want to extend an offer. Made a grown man cry.

title: Can You Solve This Problem in Less Than 5 Minutes?
content:

Some words are too long, making them tedious to write repeatedly. If a word's length is greater than 10, we shorten it using the first and last letters, with the number of characters in between. Otherwise, the word remains unchanged.
For example:
✏️ "localization" → "l10n"
✏️ "internationalization" → "i18n"

🔢 The first line contains an integer n (1 ≤ n ≤ 100), the number of words.
📄 The next n lines each contain a single word (1 to 100 characters).
📤 Output
🖨️ Print n lines, each containing the transformed word.
🎯 Example
📌 Input:
4
word
localization
internationalization
pneumonoultramicroscopicsilicovolcanoconiosis

word
l10n

title: Games24x7 | SDE(Data Engineer) | 1.8 YOE
content:
About the Company:
Games 24x7 is an Indian online gaming company known for RummyCircle and My11Circle, offering skill-based card games and fantasy sports. It is also an official partner of the Indian Premier League (IPL).
Years of Experience (YOE): 1.8 YOE
Verdict: SELECTED 🎉
I had the opportunity to interview with Games 24x7, where I went through four rounds of interviews. The first two were technical, followed by a discussion with the Director of Engineering, and the final round was conducted by the company's CEO and Founder.
1st Round (Technical)
DSA: Questions on Kadane’s Algorithm, Binary Search, and BFS (Leetcode Medium). The interviewer explored different approaches to solving the problems.
Project Discussion, Optimization of ETL pipelines, high-level architecture of Spark, reasons for choosing Spark over Hive, real-time analytics project, Kafka ingestion, and compression techniques.
SQL: Advanced SQL queries based on different scenarios, including window functions.
2nd Round (Technical)
Project Discussion: Spark performance tuning, AWS services listed in my resume, and team structure in my previous company.
Spark SQL(Handling nested JSON), schema consistency.
Data Partitioning, Concepts of coalesce and repartition, Delta tables (extensive discussions on these topics with various scenario-based questions.
3rd Round (Problem Solving ability)
I was unsure whether this would be a technical or cultural fit round, but it turned out to be a problem-solving discussion. The interviewer assessed my ability to think outside the box and your knowledge of the latest industry trends, both national and international might help in this round.
4th Round (CEO & Founder)
A 30-minute cultural fit discussion with the CEO, focusing on alignment with the company’s vision and values.
I learned a lot throughout this process and am excited for the journey ahead! 🚀
Compensation: can't give the exact figures but your in-hand will be varying from 22-26 LPA depending on your previous compensation and your negotiating skills xD + 12% of base + RSUs + JB

title: Amazon Interview Expereince - L5 - SDE 2 - Seattle
content:
OA
Problem 1:
Servers Connected in a ring configuration. Determine the minimum time to tranfer data to all servers from a given server.
Problem 2:
Very similar to knapsack problem
Outcome:
Passed all test cases on Problem 1 .
TLE for 4 test cases in problem 2.
Recruiter reached out 2 days later to schedule direct onsite.
Onsite:
Every round was about 20-30 min Leadership Principles and 30 min coding.
I had examples ready for ~10 Leadership Principles and was able to easily answer them and also handle any followup questions.
Coding 1:
Low level programming. Design a package interface and a package manager to install all necassary dependencies.
Outcome: Took some time initially to confirm the structure of the code. Finally landed on one class for a Package(dependencies = List[Package]).
Another class PackageManager that determines the order of install for a set of Packages.
Basic DFS solution with optimisation resulted in O(n) solution.
Coding 2:
Design a cache for a search system that can have filters.
Outcome: Problem was super vague and took me forever to clarify and get to the details.
Was able to only code a very rough solution with lots of comments. The code was not fully functional, but I was able to explain every part of it and the assumptions and working of every function in the class. Used HashMap and Doubly Linked list
Basically 4 concepts: Key determination, insert startegy, retrieval strategy and eviction startegy
This might have been the bar raiser mostly. Interviewer left me confused on whether I did well or not.
Coding 3:
Course Schedule 2: https://leetcode.com/problems/course-schedule-ii/
Outcome: Very straightforward. Got to the solution quickly. Explained code.
System Design:
The problem was vague but as I discussed more I finally ended up designing an ETL system.
Handled cases like long running loads, high scale, retries, logging, write performance, updates, monitoring.
Interviewer was pleased with the final design. The design was like a patch of spaghetti :P.
Recieved feedback that I passed one day after onsite. Recruiter confirmed availibilty for Hiring Manager round
Hiring Manager
Very candid discussion about the role, my experience, what I can expect, how I can grow, team structure, workflows etc.
Offer
Recieved callback next day regarding verbal offer numbers
Base: 175K
Sign On 1st year: 90K
Sign On 2nd year: 70K
RSU: 900 units
Relocation: 7k
TC year 1: ~275K
Tried to negotiate but recruiter got back saying that its the highest possible.
Result
Accepted the offer as the recruiter only gave me 1 day deadline after sending written offer.
I found this really stupid and annoying. Felt it was done only to fill their recuiter quota.
Was told that if I ask for time, I may not be considered as there are many in pipeline.
A week later I declined the offer as I got competeing offer from Apple and I preferred Apple due to Bay area location and better culture.

title: Best Advice for New Leetcode Users - Beginner's Guide
content:
The Following is a discussion set to help newcommers get an understanding of what leetcode is and how to approach solving problems and start progression. If you are a professional coder help the lead code community answering the following questions by commenting your own version of the Questions, you can answer all or only one of the questions if you feel like you're an expert only in a specific area or expert in a certain category.
Note: More Questions Will be added to consistantly keep the commuinity updated - Last Updated 18th Mar 2025
Who is This For ?
If you're a newcomer [First Week / Month / Day ] that is struggling with how to approach leaetcode and start making progress on it you're in the right place the answers that will be provided in this discussion forum will provide you with all the things you need we hope that professionals will answer this discussion so that you can have an answer for all the common questions and don't have to take more time to search for them.
Even if you're a professional this will work as a good reminder for you to stay on a good track for progression.
Approaching Problems
Q1: How can a new lead code user approach new coding problems as a beginner while he doesn't know anything to do or where to start (which language or niche or coding approach should they take as a start)?
Pick a Language – Choose a beginner-friendly language like Python or JavaScript. If aiming for job interviews, C++, Java, or Python are widely used.
Start with Easy Problems – Begin with simple problems under "Easy" difficulty.
Follow a Roadmap – Stick to a structured problem list like NeetCode 150 or Blind 75.
Understand Before Coding – Read the problem carefully, note inputs/outputs, and visualize the approach before coding.
Break It Down – Divide the problem into smaller steps and solve each step logically.
Use Debugging Tools – Print intermediate values to understand your logic.
Q2: How to align your goals as a programmer with lead code ?
Competitive Coding– If interested in coding contests, solve problems regularly and increase difficulty gradually.
Job Preparation – Focus on Data Structures & Algorithms (DSA), starting with arrays, strings, recursion, linked lists, trees, graphs, and DP.
System Design Aspirations – If you want to excel in backend interviews, focus on graph theory, databases, and optimization problems.
Software Development Practice – Solve real-world related problems and try to build projects based on learned concepts.
Q3: How to start solving problems or learn how to solve them for example should you use YouTube libraries or just look at the solution step in each problem and try to match your code with it ?
Which language to solve code with is the best for you ?
Try solving first – Even if you're stuck, think about the problem logically before checking solutions.
Learn from Solutions – After attempting, compare your approach with optimal solutions.
Use Tutorials Wisely – Follow structured tutorials like NeetCode, CS Dojo, or freeCodeCamp.
Avoid Memorization – Understand the logic instead of memorizing code patterns.
Which Language to Use?
Pick Based on Your Needs:
Python – Best for beginners, interviews, AI / ML and data science.
Java – Great for object-oriented programming and backend development.
C++ – Fast execution, commonly used in competitive programming.
JavaScript – Useful for frontend and full-stack development.
Swift/Kotlin – If you're into mobile app development.
Getting Most Benefit
Q4: How can a person get the most benefit out of solving a problem over lead code ?
Write Down the Approach – Understanding why a solution works is more important than just writing code.
Time Complexity Analysis – Check if your solution is optimal (O(n), O(log n), etc.).
Review & Reattempt – Solve the same problem after a few days without looking at past solutions.
Discuss & Learn – Participate in forums or discuss with peers.
Q5: What is the most effective way to learn while solving problems ?
Apply the "Active Recall" Technique – Try explaining your solution to someone else.
Track Progress – Use platforms like LeetCode Streaks, GitHub Repos, or a Spreadsheet to track solved problems.
Follow a Category-based Approach – Solve problems topic by topic instead of random problems.
Optimising Time & Progress
Q6: What is the best approach to dynamically keep solving problems while learning ?
Mix Easy, Medium, Hard – Start with easy problems, but introduce medium ones as you get better.
Use the "20-Minute Rule" – If stuck, spend a max of 20 minutes thinking before checking hints.
Set Weekly Goals – Example: Solve 5 problems per week focusing on one category.
Q7: How to optimise your time to solve problems while being engaged with your regular life activities ?
Use Small Time Blocks – Solve one problem a day (~30 mins).
Prioritize Problem Solving Over Tutorials – Watching too many videos can slow progress.
Practice in Intervals – Solve problems when commuting, before bed, or during breaks.
Approaching Techincal Code
Q8: How should i as a new commer approach new concepts like:
Complex statements: Break them down into smaller conditions. Write comments to simplify logic
Algorithm Optimization: Learn time complexity (Big-O notation)
Advanced Data Structures: Learn arrays → linked lists → stacks/queues → trees → graphs step by step.
Dynamic Programming Paradigms: Understand memoization vs. tabulation, solve Fibonacci, Knapsack, LCS problems first.
Recursion and Iteration tradeoffs: If recursion is slow (stack overflow risk), use loops or memoization.
Handling Edge Cases & Debugging: Always test with empty inputs, large numbers, duplicates, negative values.
Language Specific Constraints: Understand memory handling (e.g., Python is slower than C++ in some cases).
Implementing Tree or Graph Algorithms: Start with BFS, DFS, Dijkstra's algorithm before moving to *A search and MST (Minimum Spanning Tree)
Please keep your answers as simple and as consice as possible. The Aim is to help new commers and fix complicated views and make learning simple.
Thanks to all contributers !
Help others the same way you wanted to be helped

title: 🔁 Struggling to Remember Already Solved Problems? This Helped Me!
content:
Hey fellow LeetCoders,
I used to try solving problems for 30-40 minutes, but if I got stuck, I’d check hints or videos-thinking I understood them but sometimes I forget everything a week later. After repeating this mistake way too many times, I realized I needed a better way to revisit tough problems and new concepts.
Someone suggested this Chrome extension: LeetCode Reminder, and I wish I had found it sooner.
✅ It automatically reminds you to redo problems after a few days, ensuring you actually retain what you learned.
📧 The best part? It emails you at the exact time you set-whether it’s 4 days, 15 days, or any custom interval-so you don’t have to rely on memory.
Now, instead of just solving and moving on, I revisit hard or new concepts at the right time, and it's made a big difference.
If you’ve ever felt like you’re forgetting problems too quickly, you might find this useful too. Thought I’d share in case it helps someone else! 😊
Has anyone else tried something similar for revising problems or reinforcing concepts? Would love to hear your thoughts!

title: Walmart | Software Engineer 3 | Bengaluru
content:
**Education**: B.Tech in CS from an old NIT
**Years of Experience**: 2.5
**Prior Experience**: SDE 2 at an Investment Bank
**Compensation**: 21.8 LPA (21L fixed, rest variable)

```
Company: Walmart
Title/Level: Software Engineer 3 (IN3)
Location: Bengaluru, India
Salary: ₹24,50,000 (including retirals)
Stock Bonus: 25% of salary every year, vested equally over 3 years
Bonus: 20% of salary
Joining Bonus: ₹2L
Total Compensation: ~₹37L
First-Year Compensation: ~₹33L
```
Tried negotiating the fixed pay, but HR refused, stating that the bonus payout is usually over 100% every year, which I  confirmed from others as well. Accepted the offer as there was a decent increase in total compensation, and I wanted to move out of the banking sector.

Interview experience: https://leetcode.com/discuss/interview-experience/6492160/Walmart-or-Software-Engineer-3-or-Bengaluru-or-Offer

title: Uber | L5-A | Bangalore
content:
Giving back to the leetcode community.
I appeared for the Hiring Drive in Feb 2025. 

**1st Round - DS/Algo** (Working solution was expected)
There was a dependency graph given for tasks based on execution. I had to print out right order of execution of tasks for a given task.  

**2nd Round - DS/Algo** (Working solution was expected)
Modified number of island problem

**3rd Round - LLD** (Working solution was expected)
Design a task scheduling system. Task should have some executable which should be run when it is excuted.

**4th Round - HLD** 
Get nearest restaurants for a customer. 
The interviewer focused **only** on how to store the restaturant data in DB and get the nearest restaurants for a customer. The emphasis was on DB schema and APIs. 
Further questions - 
1. What will happen if there are hot spots
2. What will happen if there are no nearby restaurants.
I designed the system using cassandra with co-rodinate hash as partitioning and clustering key.
No discussion on scale happened. I had to specifically talk about scale and fail safes.

**5th Round - HM** 
Typical manegerial questions- 30 mins
Complicated design problem which I solved - 30 mins

title: Google L3 Chances | Interview Experience
content:
Hi , I recently interviewed for an L3 position at Google and would like to get feedback from fellow Googlers regarding my interview experience.

Note:- All the ratings(SH/LH/H) I mentioned below are from my experience only, not from recruiter.

Current Experience:- 1.6 Yrs (Software Engineer at Service Based Company)

Applied:- Recruiter reached out to me.

Phone Screening:- SH ( I solve complete problem without any hint and solved follow ups as well)

After the phone screening, I received feedback from HR saying that it was positive, and they wanted to move forward with the onsite interviews.

Onsite Round 1:- SH ( I solved the problem without hints, initially i give PBDS approach for which he said if I use PBDS I have to implement its function as well otherwise i have to change approach, then i solve it using other DS with TC and code, no followups).

Onsite Round 2:- H/LH ( I got stuck midway. Unfortunately I missed a hint in the problem constraints, and interviewer said I was close. But, after the hint, I solved the problem completely, including the code and time complexity.)

Onsite Round 3:- H/LH (I explained my approach and code it as well, but stuck on Time Complexity, wasted some time, then give final TC and he was satisfied with it, then solve 1 followup with code and TC, but he said he have one more followup which he couldn't ask due to time constraints).

G&L Round:- SH/H (The interviewer asked me general HR Questions and was satisfied with my answers, I believe it should be a SH).


Can anyone with experience provide feedback on whether I should expects a call for the next steps?

title: Deliveroo || Delhivery || ScryAI || GeoServe
content:
I have cracked multiple offers from multiple companies , sharing some insights about my experience

Just a brief about me im a 2021 graduate did my btech from tier 2 college in Delhi . Started my prep from July 2024

**Offer 1**: Geoserve (Bangalore) , had 3 rounds 
* DSA (Medium level)
* Design (design architecture and database of an ecomm application catalogoue)
* Discussion with engineering Head (basic behaviour and situation based questions)


**Offer 2** : ScryAI (Gurgaon sector 48), 3 rounds
* Python Basics and advanced
* DSA and python basics (Stack based medium level question)
* HR and salary discussion

**Offer 3**: Delhlivery Gurgaon , 3 Rounds
* DSA and database basics (Coin change problem and SQL related questions)
* Low level Design Stack overflow
* Design Caching system , low level

**Offer 4:** Deliveroo Hyderabad, 4 Rounds
* Hacker Rank Test (15 MCQ)
* Take home assignment (Create a CRON String Parser)
* Live coding round add features to the cron string parser and explain the code
* Behavioural Round (Expect situation based questions)
* High level Design round :  Design a system to do a Giveaway of 6 million burgers in 10 mins, we need to ensure each users gets only 1 burger.

**Years of Experience**: 0

**Date of Offer**: October 2023 (4th Year of B.E.)  
**Joining Date**: May 2024  
**Location**: Hyderabad (Fixed)

### Compensation Details:

- **Signing Bonus**: ₹1,00,000 INR  
- **Base Pay**: ₹10,60,000 INR  
- **Relocation Bonus**: ₹3,00,000 INR (non-taxable) + ₹41,000 INR (one month basic pay)  
- **Stocks**: 4,000 USD (vested over 4 years)  
- **Performance Bonus**: 0-20% of base salary  

### Benefits:

- **Health and Hobby Reimbursement (Perks+)**: ₹30,000 INR  
- **Food Credits**: ₹200 per day  
- **Medical Insurance**: ₹5 Lakh employee + parents medical insurance (additional flex points available to increase this to ₹7 Lakh or convert them to Perks+)  
- **Transportation**: Buses and cabs to and from office  
- **Joining Kit and Goodies**: Year-end, participation, and team-specific rewards


In addition to the salary, both the employee and employer's contribution to the Provident Fund (PF) will be deducted from your monthly salary. Apart from this, you also receive a component called GP (Global Allowance), which is around ₹1,36,000 INR in your first salary. The entire tax for the year is deducted based on the tax regime (new or old) chosen, and the tax amount is approximately equivalent to the GP component of ₹1,36,000 INR. Therefore, you can consider that you won’t need to pay any tax in the first year, as the GP covers the entire tax amount. Please note that the GP component is not mentioned in the offer letter.

**In your first year, you also have the opportunity to visit Microsoft’s Seattle office for a 3-4 day event called "Accelerate", which is specially designed for new hires. This seven-day trip is fully reimbursed by Microsoft.**

*After accounting for PF and all other deductions, your take-home salary in the first year is approximately ₹78,000 INR per month.*

content:
**Education:** B.Tech in Computer Science  
**Years of Experience:** 0 years  
**Internship Experience:** 6 months (Amazon, Data Engineer Intern)  
**Prior Experience:** Interned at Amazon  

**Offer Details:**  
- **Company:** Amazon  
- **Title/Level:** Data Engineer I  
- **Location:** Bengaluru, India  
- **Date of Offer:** January 2025  

### Compensation:  
- **Base Pay (INR):** ₹15,34,000  
- **Sign-on Bonus:**  
  - Year 1: ₹4,23,000  
  - Year 2: ₹3,81,000  
- **Restricted Stock Unit (RSU) Value (INR):** ₹10,93,000 (vested over 4 years)  
  - Vesting schedule:  
    - 5% after Year 1  
    - 15% after Year 2  
    - 20% every six months thereafter until fully vested  

- **Relocation (INR):** ₹1,50,000  

**Total Compensation (First Year):**  
Base Pay + Sign-on Bonus (Year 1) + RSUs (First Year Vesting)  
= ₹15,34,000 + ₹4,23,000 + ₹54,650 (5% of ₹10,93,000)  
= **₹20,11,650**  

**Total Compensation (4 Years):**  
Base Pay (4 years) + Sign-on Bonus (2 years) + Full RSU Value  
= ₹15,34,000 \xD7 4 + ₹4,23,000 + ₹3,81,000 + ₹10,93,000  
= **₹75,55,000**  

### Benefits:  
1. **Annual Leave:**  
   - 15 working days of annual leave per financial year  
   - 12 calendar days of sick leave per financial year  
   - 12 calendar days of casual leave per financial year  
   - 10 mandatory and optional holidays per calendar year  

2. **Transportation Allowance:**  
   - Tier 1 cities (Bengaluru, Hyderabad, Chennai, Mumbai, NCR, Kolkata): ₹4,000/month  
   - Other cities: ₹1,500/month  

3. **Home Internet Reimbursement:** Up to ₹1,250/month  
4. **Meal Card:** ₹1,100/month  
5. **Insurance:** Standard Amazon insurance benefits .
